body: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office and the New York City Department of Investigation have opened separate inquiries into how a real-estate development firm in which Michael J. Lazar was a partner obtained an apparently bogus document and used it to get public financing of a $6.8 million Brooklyn apartment building. Spokesmen for both offices
title: 2 INQUIRIES ON BROOKLYN REAL-ESTATE DEAL

body: IN the heart of New York's most populous borough, Prospect Park and its verdant partner, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, wander over nearly 600 acres of meadows, woodlands, waterways and an array of theme gardens. Here in Brooklyn's great backyard are also historic houses and sculptures, a zoo and skating rink, a Japanese garden and a horticultural
title: BROOKLYN'S BEST AND BRIGHTEST; Woodlands and Exotic Gardens

body: A former City Transportation Commissioner, Michael J. Lazar, said yesterday that he had ''no involvement whatsoever'' in submitting an apparently bogus document for a Brooklyn housing project. Copies of the document, a certificate of occupancy, were filed in July 1984 with state and city housing agencies by a developer, Rose Garden Associates. Mr.
title: METRO DATELINES; Lazar Denies Housing Role

body: A real-estate development firm in which Michael J. Lazar was a partner submitted an apparently fictitious document to Federal, state and city agencies that cleared the way for permanent public financing of a $6.8 million apartment building in Brooklyn, according to governmental records. Copies of the document, a certificate of occupancy, were filed
title: LAZAR FIRM SAID TO FILE FALSE PAPER

body: ABBREVIATIONS USED IN TABLES Following are the unofficial results in Tuesday's general election. Abbreviations are: D - Democrat, R - Republican, C - Conservative, L - Liberal, RTL - Right to Life. (U) denotes an unopposed candidate. An asterisk (*) denotes an incumbent. The votes of minor party candidates will not be available until official
title: THE ELECTIONS: FACTS AND FIGURES; Tallies for U.S. Senator and Statewide Offices

body: THREE years ago, to protect the character of brownstone streets and neighborhoods of low-rise apartment buildings throughout New York City, the Planning Commission established new zoning districts that allow builders to put up bulkier but lower buildings. Although applicable in principle throughout the city, the zoning was devised with the Upper
title: A High-Coverage Project in Queens

body: ''IT'S a roller-coaster experience - I wouldn't mind the ups and downs so much if there was a stretch between the peaks and valleys,'' said Ralph Strafaci, an airline executive. title: Making a Town-House Dream a Reality

body: To the Editor: In the interest of accuracy, I would like to note that the legal suit that you mentioned in your article on March 2 entitled ''The Stakes in Contextual Zoning'' was filed by the Citizens for the Preservation of Windsor Terrace with the urging and the support of elected officials at several levels of government. title: HELPING HANDS IN ZONING SUIT

body: AT City Hall and in Albany, public officials dwell upon their eagerness to stimulate housing construction. But in many neighborhoods where development might occur, homeowner groups supported by elected officials have succeeded in thwarting high-rise intrusions. title: PERSPECTIVES: HIGH-RISE HOUSING; THE STAKES IN 'CONTEXTUAL ZONING'
